document.title: New Jersey Student Learning Standards English Language Arts (NJSLS-ELA)

9DA708FCA2FC4E948AD5BF894D6EC163.description:
Adapt speech to a variety of contexts and tasks, demonstrating a command of formal
English when indicated or appropriate.

346EB201B8C144F6AE97B6F8E18840B5.description:
Make strategic use of digital media (e.g., textual, graphical, audio, visual, and interactive
elements) in presentations to enhance understanding of findings, reasoning, and evidence and to add
interest.

4FC94570BEF24BE3BE186A0ADAE2C194.description:
Present information, findings and supporting evidence clearly, concisely, and logically. The
content, organization, development, and style are appropriate to task, purpose, and audience.

A237DE401DCE4D07B795E8EB047ABD70.description:
Evaluate a speaker’s point of view, reasoning, and use of evidence and rhetoric, assessing
the stance, premises, links among ideas, word choice, points of emphasis, and tone used.

6DEE86667560421CB8A3EE93D31E12E3.description:
Integrate multiple sources of information presented in diverse formats and media (e.g.,
visually, quantitatively, orally) in order to make informed decisions and solve problems, evaluating the
credibility and accuracy of each source and noting any discrepancies among the data.

9CF34B564ED147869296F63BE51DD813.description:
Respond thoughtfully to diverse perspectives; synthesize comments, claims, and
evidence made on all sides of an issue; resolve contradictions when possible; and
determine what additional information or research is required to deepen the
investigation or complete the task.

5606203D7A9B443EB7650F891E028903.description:
Propel conversations by posing and responding to questions that probe reasoning and
evidence; ensure a hearing for a full range of positions on a topic or issue; clarify, verify,
or challenge ideas and conclusions; and promote divergent and creative perspectives.

2B1DAD3B72C54F1082E58E58C1A5CF00.description:
Collaborate with peers to promote civil, democratic discussions and decision-making, set
clear goals and assessments (e.g., student developed rubrics), and establish individual
roles as needed.

9F470461757A4A3EA4774541FA4AF988.description:
Come to discussions prepared, having read and researched material under study;
explicitly draw on that preparation by referring to evidence from texts and other
research on the topic or issue to stimulate a thoughtful, well-reasoned exchange of
ideas.

F79E3873B02F45E39B27E9B672BBCD5C.description:
Initiate and participate effectively in a range of collaborative discussions (one-on-one, in
groups, and teacher-led) with peers on grades 11–12 topics, texts, and issues, building on others’ ideas
and expressing their own clearly and persuasively.

06A762A0FFF6446DA9D2BC06CAB773CE.description:
Write routinely over extended time frames (time for research, reflection, and revision)
and shorter time frames (a single sitting or a day or two) for a range of tasks, purposes.

3711EED4E95C4453A26055E8A24CE2CB.description:
Gather relevant information from multiple authoritative print and digital sources, using
advanced searches effectively; assess the strengths and limitations of each source in terms of the task,
purpose, and audience; integrate information into the text selectively to maintain the flow of ideas,
avoiding plagiarism and overreliance on any one source and following a standard format for citation
(MLA or APA Style Manuals).

0317095AC4E743D0A12A63C982D2F162.description:
Conduct short as well as more sustained research projects to answer a question
(including a self-generated question) or solve a problem; narrow or broaden the inquiry when
appropriate; synthesize multiple sources on the subject, demonstrating understanding of the subject
under investigation.

7B28FF1CB8D44951A76ABF76766781E3.description:
Develop and strengthen writing as needed by planning, revising, editing, rewriting, trying
a new approach; sustaining effort to complete complex writing tasks; tracking and reflecting on personal
writing progress (e.g., using portfolios, journals, conferencing); or consulting a style manual (such as MLA
or APA Style), focusing on addressing what is most significant for a specific purpose and audience.

9F989295F7754A58A3FBC6E3E3AC61DC.description:
Provide a conclusion that follows from and reflects on what is experienced, observed, or
resolved over the course of the narrative.

64831D2363194CDABA3FD6DF514D0664.description:
Use precise words and phrases, telling details, and sensory language to convey a vivid
picture of the experiences, events, setting, and/or characters.

E1A6C4879254465CA5AEB9FA5B04636A.description:
Use a variety of techniques to sequence events so that they build on one another to
create a coherent whole and build toward a particular tone and outcome (e.g., a sense
of mystery, suspense, growth, or resolution).

7E4C44453065476B98DAE35433215CC4.description:
Use narrative techniques, such as dialogue, pacing, description, reflection, and multiple
plot lines, to develop experiences, events, and/or characters.

04FE9213FB904B0EA391379ED71213F4.description:
Engage and orient the reader by setting out a problem, situation, or observation and its
significance, establishing one or multiple point(s) of view, and introducing a narrator
and/or characters; create a smooth progression of experiences or events.

0D053C1AA85342FC9880EAE31B9D5937.description:
Write narratives to develop real or imagined experiences or events using effective
technique, well-chosen details, and well-structured event sequences.

8F081FFB96704A3E990C648EA8134C16.description:
Provide a concluding paragraph or section that supports the argument presented (e.g.,
articulating implications or the significance of the topic).

1ECC098654154D9495CD7E273B905EB1.description:
Establish and maintain a style and tone appropriate to the audience and purpose (e.g.,
formal and objective for academic writing) while attending to the norms and
conventions of the discipline in which they are writing.

43825966C9444470969F2B51DB6E9E24.description:
Use precise language, domain-specific vocabulary, and techniques such as metaphor,
simile, and analogy to manage the complexity of the topic.

C1F61C9AB88E4FB88FD5535192C57BA5.description:
Use appropriate and varied transitions and syntax to link the major sections of the text,
create cohesion, and clarify the relationships among complex ideas and concepts.

E5E6BB0A62914893AB41CDB0BEF9E01A.description:
Develop the topic thoroughly by selecting the most significant and relevant facts,
extended definitions, concrete details, quotations, or other information and examples
appropriate to the audience’s knowledge of the topic.

7035DD30C10D40A0A37C6B7D0892E25E.description:
Introduce a topic; organize complex ideas, concepts, and information so that each new
element builds on that which precedes it to create a unified whole; include formatting
(e.g., headings), graphics (e.g., figures, tables), and multimedia when useful to aiding
comprehension.

D2DF337BBF04479EBBA047B7C233E7A9.description:
Write informative/explanatory texts (including the narration of historical events, scientific
procedures/ experiments, or technical processes) to examine and convey complex ideas, concepts, and
information clearly and accurately through the effective selection, organization, and analysis of content.

3DED1D4B5BB4469C81DC6228931DE2A1.description:
Provide a concluding paragraph or section that supports the argument presented (e.g.,
articulating implications or the significance of the topic).

3E967E17FFEE4591846F39052212CEDB.description:
Establish and maintain a style and tone appropriate to the audience and purpose (e.g.,
formal and objective for academic writing) while attending to the norms and
conventions of the discipline in which they are writing.

630C7BC97B154123944462161D8262B5.description:
Use transitions (e.g., words, phrases, clauses) to link the major sections of the text,
create cohesion, and clarify the relationships between claim(s) and reasons, between
reasons and evidence, and between claim(s) and counterclaims.

53BFA965CF6B4BF18F24314E10220C61.description:
Develop claim(s) and counterclaims avoiding common logical fallacies and using sound
reasoning and thoroughly, supplying the most relevant evidence for each while pointing
out the strengths and limitations of both in a manner that anticipates the audience’s
knowledge level, concerns, values, and possible biases.

80E111F5F0CC4E5A9F6C20CBBA1EECAF.description:
Introduce precise, knowledgeable claim(s), establish the significance of the claim(s),
distinguish the claim(s) from alternate or opposing claims, and create an organization
that logically sequences claim(s), counterclaims, reasons, and evidence.

A292161D8523482AB230E2EF5C159840.description:
Write arguments to support claims in an analysis of substantive topics or texts, using
valid reasoning and relevant and sufficient evidence.

6F2ED9B9163A4CF48E89C800D06E80A4.description:
Analyze and reflect on (e.g., practical knowledge, historical/cultural context, and
background knowledge) documents of historical and scientific significance for their purposes, including
primary source documents relevant to U.S. and/or global history and texts proposing scientific or
technical advancements.

0147801936F14A2999DFF04E1FC52A4B.description:
Demonstrate knowledge of, analyze, and reflect on (e.g., practical knowledge,
historical/cultural context, and background knowledge) documents of historical and literary significance
for their themes, purposes, and rhetorical features, including how two or more texts from the same
period treat similar themes or topics.

33680A64CA0649D78C66A87FA4EF832A.description:
Describe and evaluate the reasoning in seminal U.S. and global texts, and the premises,
purposes, and arguments in these works.

15928BE1E1094D809D6DB42B3CCFAA8F.description:
Synthesize complex information across multiple sources and formats to develop ideas,
resolve conflicting information, or develop an interpretation that goes beyond explicit text information
(e.g., express a personal point of view, new interpretation of the concept).

20C79CB357E94F9A80E5234FC5BDEB0F.description:
Synthesize complex information across multiple sources and formats to develop ideas,
resolve conflicting information, or develop an interpretation that goes beyond explicit text information
(e.g., express a personal point of view, new interpretation of the author’s message).

839A4F507D784CE49044846D4C1F4419.description:
Analyze an author’s purpose in a text distinguishing what is directly stated in a text or
through rhetoric, analyzing how style and content convey information and advance a point of view.

CF5A64077CAD4649A345FA830FA2C81F.description:
Evaluate perspectives/lenses from two or more texts on related topics and justify the
more cogent viewpoint (e.g., different accounts of the same event or issue, use of different media or
formats).

23216D2EACC24CA69D4BE6749BB52CAF.description:
Evaluate the author’s choices concerning structure and the effectiveness of the structure
an author uses in his or her exposition or argument, including whether the structure makes points clear,
convincing, and engaging.

B868EFF267CA4858923E93D5E78BDE03.description:
Evaluate the author’s choices concerning the structure and the effectiveness of specific
parts of a text (e.g., the choice of where to begin or end a story, the choice to provide a comedic or tragic
resolution) and how they contribute to its overall structure and meaning, as well as its aesthetic impact.

ED0D00F94E824E5EA24A9C625392E0BF.description:
Analyze the impact of an author's choices as they develop ideas throughout the text
regarding a complex set of ideas or sequence of events, and explain how specific individuals, ideas, or
events interact and develop.

A50F3E2C97D046CDA13DCF654C08F00D.description:
Analyze the impact of the author’s choices as they develop ideas throughout the text
regarding how to develop and relate elements of a story or drama (e.g., where a story is set, how the
action is ordered, how the characters are introduced and developed).

0C0100647AE34B22894529A2539032CD.description:
Determine two or more central ideas of an informational text and analyze how they are
developed and refined over the course of a text, including how they interact and build on one another to
provide a complex account or analysis; provide an objective summary of the text.

EC2904364646445B938A7A284D363A2B.description:
Determine two or more themes of a literary text and analyze how they are developed and
refined over the course of the text, including how they interact and build on one another to produce a
complex account or analysis; provide an objective summary of the text.

086D166DEDF747069D8A6A81BD058520.description:
Accurately cite a range of thorough textual evidence and make relevant connections to
strongly support a comprehensive analysis of multiple aspects of what an informational text says
explicitly and inferentially, as well as interpretations of the text.

A8E13697A8D94400B8A467DA9436B783.description:
Accurately cite strong and thorough textual evidence and make relevant connections to
strongly support a comprehensive analysis of multiple aspects of what a literary text says explicitly and
inferentially, as well as interpretations of the text; this may include determining where the text leaves
matters uncertain.

9CCC9338E0F7425DB57C5581D22CF009.description:
Analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone, including language
that is particularly fresh, engaging, or beautiful.

52CFDB9B91764E30AF986A134AEF0FC2.description:
Analyze how the meaning of a key term or terms develops or is refined over the course
of a text.

5D4BFF1C6CAE48C5AC206A0362450F4A.description: Analyze nuances in the meaning of words with similar denotations.

0D0DB1F2DBAC4EB49B989C03E577324B.description:
Interpret figures of speech (e.g., hyperbole, paradox) in context and analyze their role in
the text.

D8C4C25EBE274CB3A0DD0DAD70FAC07B.description:
Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in
word meanings, including connotative meanings.

CC9EE7E2329F44CA8DC66248860A4CBA.description:
Verify the preliminary determination of the meaning of a word or phrase (e.g., by
checking the inferred meaning in context or in a dictionary).

6134DC54B096465E942B3B6517083E80.description:
Consult general and specialized reference materials (e.g., dictionaries, glossaries,
thesauruses), both print and digital, to find the pronunciation of a word or determine or
clarify its precise meaning, its part of speech, its etymology, or its standard usage.

BA167E546ECC4CE7B151F171F8D74D5D.description:
Analyze how an author or speaker uses and refines the meaning of a key term or terms
over the course of a text or discussion.

637BC2D3EF134E6E8D1E71E716F60FAB.description:
Identify and correctly use patterns of word changes that indicate different meanings or
parts of speech (e.g., conceive, conception, conceivable).

B9C73128A6C14EBC943BCE98B50D9837.description:
Use context (e.g., the overall meaning of a sentence, paragraph, or text; a word’s
position or function in a sentence) as a clue to the meaning of a word or phrase.

6769C63DECB14275B35FC68F64D64E3B.description:
Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases
based on grades 11–12 reading and content, including technical meanings, choosing flexibly from a range
of strategies.

717C8A5340E9423CB0ABEA97468ED721.description:
Demonstrate independence in gathering vocabulary knowledge when considering a
word or phrase important to comprehension or expression.

1F77DBDC56464188B5A7B1DEAD2BAE22.description: Vary syntax for effect, apply an understanding of syntax to the study of complex texts.

F222526FE29D4874832CBE0FB13CBE05.description:
Acquire and use accurately general academic and domain-specific words and phrases,
sufficient for reading, writing, speaking, and listening at the college and career readiness
level.

CCE9C3CD5C884B33A9F6B5500E95FE44.description:
Apply knowledge of language to understand how language functions in different contexts,
to make effective choices for meaning or style, and to comprehend more fully when reading or listening.

EC4CBB53BB6B4731892865B0007EEA7B.description:
Apply the understanding that usage is a matter of convention, can change over time, and
place, and is sometimes contested.

8AD244984DFB4A159180A8E241F6BCBE.description:
Demonstrate command of the system and structure of the English language when writing
or speaking.
